Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: Tonight was supposed to be ours. My boyfriend and I had circled this evening on the calendar weeks ago, the only open slot before I’d be working nights and he’d be out of town. He’d planned dinner, even picked up my favorite wine. But as I was getting ready to leave work, my supervisor called. The new ambulance was missing some supplies, and protocol demanded a full check before tomorrow’s shift. I was the only one available. I stared at the first-aid kit, ticking off items, my phone buzzing with his messages: “Can’t wait to see you!” and “Should I start the pasta?” My heart twisted. I knew how much this night meant to him, to us. But I also knew the responsibility I carried—if I missed something, a patient could suffer. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to wait. I stood in the supply room, torn, the clock ticking louder with every passing second.
